description: From Irish bróg (“boot, shoe”), from Old Irish bróc, itself from Old Norse brók (“breeches”). The "accent" sense may instead be derived from Irish barróg (“a hold (on the tongue)”).

entries.meaning: A strong dialectal accent. In Ireland it used to be a term for Irish spoken with a strong English accent, but gradually changed to mean English spoken with a strong Irish accent as English control of Ireland gradually increased and Irish waned as the standard language.
examples: I had no doubt he knew where I was from, for I had the brogue, although not much of it.

entries.meaning: A strong Oxford shoe, with ornamental perforations and wing tips.
(dated) A heavy shoe of untanned leather.

verbs.description: brogue (third-person singular simple present brogues, present participle broguing, simple past and past participle brogued)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To speak with a brogue (accent).
(transitive) To punch a hole in, as with an awl.

verbs.description: brogue (third-person singular simple present brogues, present participle broguing, simple past and past participle brogued)

entries.meaning: (dialect) to fish for eels by disturbing the waters.
